segments.text: Personal log, day 87. I'm in the Cupola for evening Earth observation. It never gets old.
We're passing over the Mediterranean right now. I can see the coast of Italy, the boot shape is so clear from up here.
The water is this incredible deep blue. And I can see the clouds forming over the Alps. Weather systems look so peaceful from 420 kilometers.
You know, ground control asked me yesterday if I ever get homesick. The answer is complicated.
I miss my family, sure. I miss the smell of rain, fresh coffee that doesn't come from a pouch, the feeling of wind.
But then I look at Earth from this perspective, and I realize how lucky I am to be one of the few humans who gets to see this.
We're crossing into North Africa now. I can see the Sahara Desert, this vast expanse of tan and gold.
The Nile River cuts through it like a green ribbon. From here, you can see how crucial that river is to civilization.
All those cities clustered along the water. The desert is empty, but the river is life.
Tomorrow's EVA is going to be intense. Torres and Kim are ready, I'm confident in that. But there's always risk.
Every time someone goes outside, I feel the weight of command. Their lives depend on the decisions I make.
We've trained for every contingency, checked every system twice. But space doesn't forgive mistakes.
Okay, enough heavy thoughts. We're approaching the terminator line. Sunrise in about two minutes.
This is my favorite part of the orbit. The way the light shifts from darkness to that thin blue line, then full daylight.
We see 16 sunrises every day up here. Sixteen sunsets. It should feel ordinary, but it never does.
There it is. The light is touching the edge of the planet now. The atmospheric layers are visible - purple, blue, orange.
That thin blue line is everything. All of human history happened in that fragile layer of atmosphere.
Every person who's ever lived, every war, every discovery, every love story - all contained in that delicate shell.
It changes you, seeing it this way. The borders we draw, the conflicts we have - from here, they seem so arbitrary.
We're one planet, one ecosystem. The atmosphere doesn't care about politics or nationalism.
And now we're in full sunlight. The Indian Ocean is below us. I can see Madagascar, the distinctive shape of the island.
There's a typhoon forming to the east. You can see the spiral structure, the eye starting to develop.
From up here, it's beautiful. But I know that down there, people are preparing evacuations, boarding up windows.
That's the paradox of this view. Everything looks peaceful and perfect, but we know the reality is more complex.
I'm taking some photographs for the Earth observation database. Scientists requested high-res images of coral reef systems.
They're monitoring bleaching events due to ocean temperature changes. Our position gives them unique perspective.
There's the Great Barrier Reef now. Even from orbit, you can see the color variations in the water.
Capturing images... got them. I'll downlink these in the next communication window.
My daughter asked me in our last video call what Earth looks like from space. I told her it's the most beautiful thing I've ever seen.
She's eight years old. By the time she's my age, maybe trips to orbit will be commonplace. Maybe she'll see this view herself.
That's the hope, isn't it? That we're paving the way for the next generation to explore even further.
Alright, we're about to pass over Australia. Time to head back. Dinner is in thirty minutes, and I need to review tomorrow's flight plan one more time.
But I'll be back here tomorrow evening. Same time, same window. Different part of Earth, same sense of wonder.
End personal log.

environment.background_sounds: quiet ventilation, occasional camera shutter, gentle equipment hum
